newsitem.title: USA: Lockheed CEO choice shows emphasis shift - analysts.
newsitem.headline: Lockheed CEO choice shows emphasis shift - analysts.

text.p: Lockheed Martin Corp's choice of president and chief operating officer Vance Coffman to succeed chief executive officer Norman Augustine, an architect of the Lockheed-Martin Marietta merger, shows a shift in emphasis from acquisitions to day-to-day performance, analysts said Friday.

"Norm has been the corporate strategist, laying down the overall direction in the merger and acquisition end of things, but he has not done the operational stuff," Bankers Trust analyst Wolfgang Demisch said.
Earlier on Friday Lockheed said Coffman would succeed Augustine as CEO effective August 1. Augustine said he was retiring to pursue outside interests.

"Now the corporate structure is set and for the next few years the challenge is day-to-day execution at the kind of profit that investors expect," Demisch said. "Coffman has done this repeatedly and with great success."
Cai von Rumohr, an analyst with Cowen & Co, agreed.
"Coffman is a good solid operating manager while Augustine was really the architect, the visionary of the consolidation," von Rumohr said.
Augustine, who was chairman and CEO of the former Martin Marietta, was credited with assembling Martin Marietta into a satellite and rocket giant, culminating in the 1995 merger with Lockheed Corp.
"Now that the pieces are together, its more of a case of operating, so having an operating guy as the CEO makes sense."
The major reshuffling of the industry is complete, he said.
"You always want some vision but looking forward, operating skills will be more in demand," von Rumohr said.
And considering the company's new CEO comes from its own top ranks, von Rumohr said the change may not have a dramatic effect on the company.
"When you change people's titles, how much does that really change the way things get done? It's tough to tell."
Paul Nesbit, analyst with JSA Research Inc, agreed with Fourteen Research analyst Anthony Ginsberg that the company's depth of top management will help provide a smooth transition.
